channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: India Ink: An Afghan Church Grows in Delhi
item.description: Afghan coverts to Christianity find refuge in Delhi.
item.category: United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees
item.dc:creator: By NEYAZ FAROOQUEE
item.media:description: A still from a television program that shows Abdul Rahman, right, who converted from Islam to Christianity, holding a translated version of the Bible at a court in Kabul, Afghanistan, on Mar. 23, 2006.

item.title: European Union Adds Hezbollah to Terror List
item.description: An effort led by Britain brought a unanimous decision against the group’s military wing. Sanctions are expected to include travel bans and asset freezes.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES KANTER

item.title: Wave of Violence Continues in Iraq
item.description: A suicide bomber drove into an army patrol on Monday, killing 13 people in Mosul, and on Sunday night, 29 people were killed in coordinated attacks on two prisons in Baghdad.
item.dc:creator: By DURAID ADNAN
item.media:description: Women walked past a building in Baghdad that was damaged in one of the bombings that killed dozens over the weekend.

item.title: Across Syria, Violent Day of Attacks and Ambush
item.description: Government forces killed dozens of rebels in an ambush east of Damascus, fighters linked to Al Qaeda battled Kurdish militias and Syria’s military peppered an outdoor market with mortar rounds.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD and HWAIDA SAAD

item.title: Iraq: 25 Security Forces Dead in Prison Raid
item.description: Officials said a suicide attack against an army patrol in the northern city of Mosul killed nine soldiers and three civilians, and injured 14 others.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: U.S. Navy Says Jettisoned Bombs Pose No Threat to Great Barrier Reef
item.description: The United States Navy said that it released four unarmed bombs into the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park during a training exercise to avoid damaging several vessels that had entered the area.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization
item.dc:creator: By MATT SIEGEL

item.title: Suicide Bomber Attacks Iraq Army Convoy, Killing 25
item.description: A suicide bomber attacked an Iraqi army convoy in the northern city of Mosul early on Monday, killing at least 22 soldiers and three passers-by, police said.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Royal Family Says Duchess of Cambridge in Labor
item.description: In the early hours on Monday, the duchess, the former Kate Middleton, was admitted to St. Mary’s Hospital in London to prepare for the birth of her first child.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: The Duchess of Cambridge, the former Kate Middleton, arrived at St. Mary’s Hospital in London on Monday for the birth of her first child.

item.title: Earthquakes Hit Area of Northwestern China
item.description: The authorities said 56 people had been confirmed dead after a series of quakes, one with a magnitude of 6.6, shook parts of Gansu Province.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER
item.media:description: Firefighters carried an injured woman after a series of deadly earthquakes struck Gansu Province on Monday.

item.title: Earthquakes Hit Area of Northwestern China
item.description: The state news media reported that 22 people had been confirmed dead after a series of temblors, one with a 6.6 magnitude, shook parts of Gansu Province.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER
item.media:description: People stood outside their homes after an earthquake in Gansu Province on Monday.

item.title: Strong Earthquake in Western China Kills 20 People
item.description: A strong earthquake struck a rural part of western China on Monday morning, killing at least 20 people and injuring 296, according to the local government.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Promising ‘Real Revolution,’ Israeli Jolts Race for Chief Rabbi
item.description: Rabbi David Stav has set off the most bitter battle in Israel’s history to lead the rabbinate.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:credit: Rina Castelnuovo for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rabbi David Stav, 53, conducting a Torah lesson in Shoham, Israel. The race to lead the rabbinate, which controls marriage, divorce and conversions, has become a public and bitter battle.

item.title: Taiwan Debates Medical Parole for Ex-Leader
item.description: An emotional debate is unfolding over whether Chen Shui-bian, a former president serving a 20-year prison term for corruption, should be granted medical parole.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Chen Shui-bian, Taiwan’s former president, in 2012. He is serving a 20-year prison term for corruption.

item.title: Seasoned Hand in Mideast May Shepherd Peace Talks
item.description: Martin Indyk, the former American ambassador to Israel, is a leading candidate to head a new team to manage Israel-Palestinian peace talks, diplomats said.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Files Suggest a Graft Case in China May Expand
item.description: Newly revealed documents suggest that GlaxoSmithKline will not be the only global drug company to come under scrutiny as China widens its investigation.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID BARBOZA
item.media:description: A Chinese flag at GlaxoSmithKline offices in Shanghai, where Glaxo is accused of using travel agencies to make bribes.

item.title: Egypt Denies Morsi and U.S. Joined in a Plot
item.description: Cairo denied an Egyptian newspaper’s report that Mohamed Morsi, the ousted president, had plotted with the American ambassador to run the country from a Cairo mosque.
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM and MAYY EL SHEIKH

item.title: Election Win by Ruling Party Signals Change in Japan
item.description: By securing control of both houses of parliament for up to three years, Sunday’s win offers Prime Minister Shinzo Abe the chance to be the most transformative leader in a decade.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER
item.media:description: Workers emptied ballot boxes as vote counting began for the election in Japan's upper house of Parliament.

item.title: Across Syria, Violent Day of Attacks and Ambush
item.description: Government forces killed dozens of rebels in an ambush east of Damascus, fighters linked to Al Qaeda battled Kurdish militias and Syria’s military peppered an outdoor market with mortar rounds.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD and HWAIDA SAAD

item.title: Strong Earthquake Strikes Central China: USGS
item.description: A strong and shallow earthquake struck central China on Monday, the United States Geological Survey said.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Afghans See Their Army Woo Them With Piety
item.description: Commanders are stressing their soldiers’ faith in Islam in an effort to combat the branding of the army as a secular, corrupt puppet of foreigners.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Col. Hayatullah Aqtash of the Afghan Army speaking to tribal elders in Chawke, telling them that “God and the Prophet” had given him the responsibility to protect them. “If you shoot at me, you shoot at them,” he said.

item.title: Thathri Journal: Setbacks From Within in Struggle to End Kashmir’s Violence
item.description: The discovery of an unexploded grenade outside the police station in Thathri, Kashmir, had some people fearing that the recent relative quiet in the region might not last.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS
item.media:credit: Kuni Takahashi for The New York Times
item.media:description: A road in Indian-controlled Kashmir, where bloody clashes had quieted down. A police officer in Thathri has been accused of being the mastermind of bombing and assassination attempts.

item.title: Wave of Attacks Widens in Iraq
item.description: Bombings and shootings in Iraq killed 13 people on Sunday, as the toll from a wave of bombings and other attacks on Saturday rose above 70.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Colombian Rebels Kill 19 Soldiers
item.description: In the bloodier of two clashes, 15 soldiers protecting an oil pipeline under construction were killed in Arauca Province when they were attacked with explosives.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Riding the New Silk Road
item.description: A look at Hewlett-Packard’s new shipping corridor along the route of the ancient Silk Road.

item.title: Pakistan Battles Polio, and Its People’s Mistrust
item.description: Anger over American foreign policy, Taliban interference and isolated killings have hindered a campaign to protect the country’s children from the disease.
item.dc:creator: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A child received a polio vaccine in a volatile neighborhood on the outskirts of Karachi, Pakistan.
